  • Hypothesis

Can exogamy be inferred from arrow points? A case study from the American Southeast

Author
Affiliation
Robert Z. Selden, Jr.

Heritage Research Center, Stephen F. Austin State University; Department of Biology, Stephen F. Austin State University; Texas Archeological Research Laboratory, The University of Texas at Austin; and Cultural Heritage Department, Jean Monnet University

Published

November 27, 2022

“The question of questions for mankind—the problem which underlies all others, and is more deeply interesting than any other—is the ascertainment of the place which man occupies in nature, and of his relation to the universe of things.” –H. Thomas Henry Huxley, Man’s Place in Nature

Hypothesis

The Caddo division of labor suggests that—generally—men were the manufacturers of lithic tools and arrow points, which is supported by the ethnographic literature, and if the material/s in each (individual; not group) burial were personal property and not offerings—also supported by the ethnographic literature—then the null hypothesis (H0) would be that males adopted the knapping traditions/idiosyncrasies of their new community, while another (H1) would be that they retained the knapping traditions/idiosyncrasies associated with their natal community. Support for the null hypothesis is expected in instances where arrow points from individual burials in a community were largely homogenous; alternatively, the inverse would provide support for H1.
